hints_html:
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

\(\displaystyle a = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}\)

and

\(\displaystyle b = \prod_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}^{f_{i}}\)

where we use all the same primes above in the two expansions so we will allow the possibility of \(\displaystyle e_{i}\) or \(\displaystyle f_{i}\) to be 0 (but of course not both). Then

\(\displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\)

and

\(\displaystyle \text{lcm}(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})}\).

See how to finish the argument.

hints_raw:
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

<math> \displaystyle a = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}</math>

and

<math> \displaystyle b = \prod_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}^{f_{i}}</math>

where we use all the same primes above in the two expansions so we will allow the possibility of <math> \displaystyle e_{i} </math> or <math> \displaystyle f_{i} </math> to be 0 (but of course not both). Then

<math> \displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})} </math>

and

<math> \displaystyle \text{lcm}(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} </math>.

See how to finish the argument.
sols_html:
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

\(\displaystyle a = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}\)

and

\(\displaystyle b = \prod_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}^{f_{i}}\)

where we use all the same primes above in the two expansions so we will allow the possibility of \(\displaystyle e_{i}\) or \(\displaystyle f_{i}\) to be 0 (but of course not both). Then

\(\displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\)

and

\(\displaystyle \text{lcm}(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})}\).

Now, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\ &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \end{aligned}\]

As

\(\displaystyle \min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i}) = e_{i} + f_{i}\)

we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\ &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\ &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}+f_{i}}\\ &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{f_{i}}\\ &= ab\end{aligned}\]

completing the proof.
sols_latex:
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

$\displaystyle a = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}$

and

$\displaystyle b = \prod_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}^{f_{i}}$

where we use all the same primes above in the two expansions so we will
allow the possibility of $\displaystyle e_{i}$ or $\displaystyle f_{i}$
to be 0 (but of course not both). Then

$\displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}$

and

$\displaystyle \text{lcm}(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})}$.

Now, we have

\begin{align*}
\gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} 
\end{align*}

As

$\displaystyle \min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i}) = e_{i} + f_{i}$

we have that

\begin{align*}
\gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}+f_{i}}\\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{f_{i}}\\
&= ab
\end{align*}

completing the proof.
sols_raw:
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

<math> \displaystyle a = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}</math>

and

<math> \displaystyle b = \prod_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}^{f_{i}}</math>

where we use all the same primes above in the two expansions so we will allow the possibility of <math> \displaystyle e_{i} </math> or <math> \displaystyle f_{i} </math> to be 0 (but of course not both). Then

<math> \displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})} </math>

and

<math> \displaystyle \text{lcm}(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} </math>.

Now, we have 

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} 
\end{align}
</math>

As 

<math> \displaystyle \min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i}) = e_{i} + f_{i}</math>

we have that 

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}+f_{i}}\\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{f_{i}}\\
&= ab
\end{align}
</math>

completing the proof.
statement_html:
Prove

In this section, prove the statement given to you.

Suppose a and b are positive integers. Show that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (a,b)[a,b] = ab.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
'''Prove'''

'''In this section, prove the statement given to you.'''

Suppose ''a'' and ''b'' are positive integers. Show that

:<math> \displaystyle
(a,b)[a,b] = ab.
</math>
